title-group.article-title: Fuzzy proportional-integral-derivative control of an overhang rotor with double discs based on the active tilting pad journal bearing

article-meta.aff: 1Environment and Reliability Center, Beijing Institute of Structure and Environment Engineering, China
2School of Astronautics, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China

author-notes.corresp: Xiaochun Gong, Environment and Reliability Center, Beijing Institute of Structure and Environment Engineering, No. 1, Dahongmen Road, Fengtai District, Beijing 100076, China Email: gxc8208@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An overhang rotor with two discs supported by a couple of tilting-pad journal bearings is investigated in this paper. The active lubrication based on injecting pressurized oil into the bearing gap through orifices machined in the bearing sliding surface is utilized to suppress the shaft vibrations. A fuzzy proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller is designed for the active lubrication to adjust the rotor-bearing equilibrium position. The finite difference method is applied to solve the pressure distribution on each tilting pad surface of the active lubricated system. Numerical simulation and experiment results show that the actively lubricated system presents effective vibration reduction of unbalance response of a flexible rotor and the fuzzy PID controller exhibits good performance. Finally the superiorities in employing the active lubricated system with regard to extending the stable operational speed ranges and manage to put off the instabilities (whirl) of the rotor-bearing system are also investigated, and clearly illustrate one of its most promising applications.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Hydrodynamic bearings have been widely used to dissipate vibration energy and keep low vibration levels in rotating machines working at severe pressure and flow conditions. The tilting pad journal bearing (TPJB) is that which shows the best stability properties among the hydrodynamic bearings. TPJB performs a main role in the behavior of rotating machinery, and has been an active research area in the last few decades. Cavalca and Dedini (1998) proposed an extension to the method of calculating the hydrodynamic forces in a simplified model of tilting pad journal bearings, and applied it to analyze the stability of vertical rotors. Castro and Cavalca (2005) adopted this proposed model to calculate experimental parameters of cylindrical bearing through an optimization algorithm. Okabe and Cavalca (2008) presented an analytical model of tilting pad bearing and compared it with an equivalent numerical model. This analytical model was shown to be up to 100 times faster than the numerical one with an acceptable precision.

It has always been believed that TPJBs are unconditionally stable, since they do not present cross coupling effects. However, such characteristics seriously depend on the rotor velocity. The oil film damping properties decreased with the increase of the rotational speed, leading the rotor-bearing system to instability and self-excited vibration (Santos and Nicoletti, 1996). Experimental results showed that TPJBs are not free from instability (mainly whirl instability) under certain operational conditions (Flack and Zuck, 1988; Lie et al., 1998). According to the literature, these conditions are low preload factor and low static loading (Olsson, 1996; White and Chan, 1992). Because of this fact, the application of control techniques to improve rotor stability has become an active area in journal bearing design.

Feedback control has also been applied to rotor-bearing systems to create these kind of mechanisms, but is still in the research and development stages. Abduljabbar et al. (1996) presented a finite element model of a rotor system with multi-bearings and the effects of rotary inertia, gyroscopic moments, internal viscous and hysteretic damping. An optimal controller was designed based on characteristics peculiar to the rotor-bearing systems which take into account the requirements for the free vibration and the persistent unbalance excitations. The results demonstrated that the proposed controller can significantly improve the dynamical behavior of a rotor-bearing system with regard to resonances and instabilities. Chen and Zhu (2008) studied a flexible rotor under seismic excitation and formulated H2, H∞ and mixed H2/H∞ control strategies by means of linear matrix inequality to attenuate the transient vibration of the flexible rotor system under a non-stationary seismic action. Nicoletti and Santos (2003) applied the active lubrication to analyze a rigid rotor-bearing system and designed both linear and nonlinear controllers to eliminate rotor-bearing instability. Numerical results showed that the application of active lubrication administrated by the active controller was effective to reduce rotor vibration and was feasible to eliminate whirl phenomena.

The stability of rotating systems supported by TPJBs is closely related to the damping characteristic of the oil film, which is reduced as the rotational speed of the machine is increased. An increase in this damping can be obtained by adapting control systems on these bearings such as hydraulic, magnetic, piezoelectric, etc. The first idea of active lubrication and experimental analysis of active TPJBs were found in the work of Santos (1993), where the control of the rotor laterals movements is made by hydraulic actuators. Since then, lots of developments in the modeling of such bearings have been achieved regarding oil film pressure estimation, oil film temperature estimation, static and dynamic property analysis, and unbalance response control (Santos and Russo, 1998; Nicoletti and Santos, 2001). The application of active lubrication to other kinds of bearings has also been investigated. For example, Wu and Pfeiffer (1998) proposed a method for theoretically estimating the oil film pressure distribution of an actively lubricated plain journal bearing. Bently et al. (2000) investigated the dynamic behavior of an actively lubricated hydrostatic bearing in the frequency domain by experiments. Santos and Watanabe (2003) explored the advantages of using control techniques to change the dynamic coefficients of a multi-recess journal bearing via active lubrication toward compensating bearing cross-coupling effects. By adopting a proper control feedback strategy and control gains, it has been shown that the stability margin of rotor-bearing systems can be significantly enlarged.

However, a number of implementation difficulties remain to be resolved before active control gains practical applications in rotating machinery. First of all the active lubrication has its own disadvantages, such as the reduction of bearing load capacity, specifically in the case of system failure. Secondly, the application of active TPJB may be greatly restricted in a rotor-bearing system with multi-disks and/or multi-bearings. Moreover, the theory and experiments for actively lubricated TPJB were developed for a simple rotor, which was considered to be rigid in Santos (2003), while the operational rotors in practical engineering are mostly flexible. Therefore, an effective control that acts very well in restraining the vibration of a flexible rotor-bearing system is crucial in practice.

This paper deals with the problem of active control for a flexible overhang rotor with two discs supported by a couple of tilting pad journal bearings. The rotor-bearing system studied here consists of two TPJBs, one of which is actively lubricated by the servo valves while the other is conventionally lubricated. The nonlinear dynamic equations are formulated and the gyroscope moment is taken into consideration on account of the rotation of the unsymmetrical rotor. A fuzzy PID controller is designed and added to the nonlinear equations of motion to change the fluid film force and consequently adjust the displacement of the rotor. Numerical and experiment simulations are carried out in order to describe the efficiency of the controlled system in reducing vibration.

sec.title: 2. Mathematical model of the rotating machinery
sec.p:
The dynamic system studied in this work is the simplified rotating machinery of the gas turbine for the sake of convenience. An overhang rotor with double discs of the gas turbine supported by two four-shoe-TPJBs is modeled as sketched in Figure 1. The shaft is considered flexible and homogeneity in equal sectional area with the rotational speed Ω. The bearing A is conventionally lubricated by the servo valves while B is actively lubricated. The masses, radial and polar moment of inertia for the two discs are mi, Jti and Jpi(i = 1, 2) respectively. l1,l2 and l3 are the lengths of three shaft segments. The radius of the shaft is r and the linear density is ρ. A typical set of parameter values for a rotor-bearing system with active TPJB used in the numerical simulations is listed in Table 1. Figure 1.
Overhang rotor active tilting pad journal bearing system with double disks.
Table 1.
Rotor-bearing and hydraulic system characteristic data
Parameter Symbol Value Unit
Disk 1 mass mo 28.25 kg
Disk 2 mass m2 50.5 kg
Bearing A mass mA 2.75 kg
Bearing B mass mB 5.5 kg
The left shaft length l1 0.25 m
The middle shaft length l1 0.25 m
The right shaft length l1 0.25 m
Shaft radius r 0.03 m
Bearing width L 0.03 m
Radial clearance c 0.0003 m
Eccentricity e 0.00015 m
Material modulus E 2.06×1011 N/m2
Total numbers of pads n 4 —
Assembled clearance h0 150.0 mm
Pad polar moment IS 2.57×10-4 kg·m2
Pre-load factor mp 0.150 —
Oil dynamic viscosity μ 0.027 N·s/m2
Oil compressibility factor βf 8.0×108 N/m2
Pipeline length lT 0.500 m
Pipeline diameter dT 0.001 m
Pipeline inner volume V0 3.93×10-7 m3
Servo valve input signal range uminmax ±0.25 V
Servo valve eigen-frequency ωV 320.0 Hz
Servo valve damping factor ξV 0.48 —
Servo valve gain KV 8.91×10-6 m3/s·V
Linearization coefficient KPQ 1.13×10-12 m3/s·V

By applying Lagrange equation and the kinetic energy of the discs, the dynamic equations of motion of the discs is achieved: (1)Mdiq··di+Cdiq·di=Qdi where (2)qdi=[xiyiθxiθyi]T,Qdi=[FexiFeyi00]T,

The subscript i = 1, 2 stands for the two discs.

According to the finite element of the Rayleigh beam, the equations of motion for the shaft segments can be expressed as (3)(Mci+Msi)q··si+Csiq·si+Ksiqsi=Qi where Csi=[Csi1Csi2Csi3Csi4]=μr2Ω60li[0-36-3li0036-3li03600-3li-3600-3li3li00-4li2-3li00li203li4li200-3li-li200363li00-363li0-36003li36003li3li00li2-3li00-4li203li-li200-3li4li20]Ksi=[Ksi1Ksi2Ksi3Ksi4]=EIrli3[1200-6li-1200-6li0126li00-126li006li4li200-6li2li20-6li004li26li002li2-12006li12006li0-12-6li0012-6li006li2li200-6li4li20-6li002li26li004li2]

Then the equations of motion for the shaft segments can be written as (5)Mriq··si+Csiq·si+Ksiqsi=Qi

and qi={xi,yi,θxi,θyi}T(i=1,2,3,4) is the generalized coordinates of the shafts (Mrij,Ksij and Csij (i, j = 1, 2, 3, 4) are the mass, stiffness and damping matrices of the shafts in equation (5), Mdi and Cdi(i=1,2) are the mass matrix and gyroscopic matrix of the discs in equation (1).

sec.title: 3. Active lubricated TPJB
sec.p:
For the implementation of the control strategy the actively lubricated bearing worked out by Santos (2003) is adopted here. It is made up of four tilting pads, in a load-on-pad configuration, as shown in Figure 2(a). The control action over the rotating shaft is made by injecting oil into the bearing gap through five machined bores in the pads (see Figure 2(b)). By coupling servo valves to the pads in the vertical and horizontal directions, the pressure of the injected oil can be controlled. Then the hydrodynamic pressure distribution in the gap may be altered among the different pads. Consequently, the vibration of the rotating shaft can be attenuated with the help of control techniques. Figure 2.
The oil injection system of the active tilting pad journal bearing; (a) active tilting pad bearing with injection system; (b) schematic view of the oil injection system of the active tilting pad bearing.

The active lubricated bearing is composed of four pads: two in the horizontal and two in the vertical direction. The fluid film pressure distribution on each pad can be obtained by solving the modified Reynolds’ equation (Santos, 1993) (7)∂∂x(hi3μ∂pi∂x)+∂∂y(hi3μ∂pi∂y)-3μl0𝔽i(x,y)pi =6U∂hi∂x+12∂hi∂t-3μl0𝔽i(x,y)Pinj, where hi is the gap between the rotor and the ith pad, μ is the oil dynamic viscosity, l0 is the orifice’s length, U is the linear velocity of the rotor surface, pi is the oil pressure in the gap between the rotor and the ith pad, Pinj is the injection pressure in the ith pad (active lubrication), 𝔽i(x,y) is a positioning function of the orifices on the pad surface and (8)𝔽i(x,y)={d02/4-η2,forη2≤d02/40,forη2>d02/4. where η=(x-xi0)2+(y-yi0)2, (xi0,yi0) is the orifice center position on the ith pad surface, and five orifices are symmetrically positioned along each pad.

The equation of motion of the ith pad can be written as (9)Isα··i=-FtiΔs=-Δs·∫apisinζda, where Is is the pad rotational inertia,αi is the angular displacement of the ith pad, Δs is the distance between the pad surface and its pivoting point, Fni=∫apicosζda,Fti=∫apisinζda are the hydrodynamic forces acting perpendicular and tangential to the pad surface, and ζ is the angle of the curvature of the pad.

The hydraulic system consists of a reservoir, two pumps and two servo valves. One of the pumps supplies the conventional lubrication to the bearing. The other pump feeds the injection system with high pressurized oil. The purpose of the servo valves is to control the pressure at which oil is injected, through the pad bores, into the bearing gap.

The dynamics of the oil flow through the servo valve are described by Santos and Russo, 1998: (11)Q··V+2ξVωVQ·V+ωV2QV=ωV2KVu(t) where QV is the oil flow through the servo valve under null loading (open ducts), ξV, ωV, KV are the damping factor, the eigen-frequency and the gain of the servo valve respectively, u(t) is the control signal.

sec.title: 4.1. Structure of adaptive fuzzy PID controller
sec.p:
The present study is intended to develop a fuzzy PID controller to suppress the shaft vibration of the active lubricated rotor-bearing system. Its configuration is shown in Figure 3, in which, a fuzzy inference module is added to conventional PID controller to adaptively tune the gain parameters kp, ki and kdaccording to the error and change in error. The structure of the fuzzy inference module includes two inputs and three outputs, where the input is error e and change in error ec, and the output is the change in gain parameters Δkp, Δki and Δkd of the PID controller. Figure 3.
Procedure of the active lubrication based on fuzzy proportional-integral-derivative control.

The error e for the active rotor TPJB system is given by the difference between the actual shaft position and the desired shaft position. For the two directions in the rotor-bearing system, one has (13){e(nT)=ζ(nT)-ζRec(nT)=e(nT)-e(nT-T) where ζ={xB,yB}T are the linear shaft displacements at bearing B, and ζR={xR,yB}T are the desired reference values of shaft positions. Here we assume that the reference bearing centre xR=yR=0.

The gains were chosen to have maximum control signal umax=0.25V when the error e is maximum xmax≡h0, ymax≡h0, then we can obtain kd0=1.766V/m, kp0=1388.14V/m and ki0=5V/m, the PID control law at maximum input signal is given by (14){uI(t)=uI*+(1.766+Δkd)(x·B-x·B*) +(1388.14+Δkp)(xB-xB*)+(5+Δki)xB,uII(t)=uII*+(1.766+Δkd)(y·B-y·B*)+(1388.14+Δkp)(y-yB*)+(5+Δki)yB.

The fuzzy inference module can adaptively regulate PID parameters online based on the nonlinear mapping relationship of inputs and outputs established according to the experience knowledge and fuzzy set theory.

sec.title: 4.2. Fuzzification of input and output variables
sec.p: The control inputs for the fuzzy controller, e(nT) and ec(nT) are converted to the fuzzy values, E(nT) and EC(nT) by the fuzzification process. Each control variable should be decomposed into a set of fuzzy regions. These regions are given unique names, called labels, within the domain of the variables. In the case of the servo valve system, the input and output space are partitioned by fuzzy sets of seven regions. Therefore, the labels used are: positive large (PB), positive medium (PM), positive small (PS), zero (Z), and negative small (NS), negative medium (NM), and negative large (NB).

Let NB be Z membership function and PB be S membership function respectively; the others are triangular membership functions. All figures of the membership functions are shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Membership functions of the input and output.

sec.title: 4.3. Establishment of fuzzy inference rule
sec.p:
Based on injecting pressurized oil into the bearing gap through orifices machined in the bearing sliding surface, the actively lubricated bearings are applied to reduce wear and vibration between rotating and stationary machinery parts. It is discovered that the voltage of the servo valve and the flow of the injected oil have an important influence upon the vibration amplitude of the rotor-active bearing system. In order to achieve the optimization of performance indexes, the fuzzy inference rules between input e, ec and output Δkp, Δki and Δkd are summarized in Table 2. Table 2.
Fuzzy rule table
e NB NM NS ZE PS PM PB
ec Δkp/Δki/Δkd
NB PB/PM/PS PB/PB/PS PM/PB/ZE PM/PB/ZE PS/PB/ZE ZE/PB/PS ZE/PM/PS
NM PB/PB/NB PB/PS/NB PM/PS/NM PS/PS/NS PS/PS/NS ZE/PS/NM ZE/PS/NM
NS PB/ZE/NB PB/ZE/NB PM/ZE/NM ZE/ZE/NS ZE/ZE/NM NS/NS/NM NS/NS/NM
ZE PB/NS/NS PM/NS/NS PS/NS/NS NS/NS/NS NM/NS/NS NM/NS/ZE NM/ZE/NM
PS PM/ZE/NB PS/ZE/NB ZE/ZE/NM NM/ZE/NS NM/ZE/NM NM/NS/ZE NM/ZE/NM
PM ZE/PB/NB ZE/PS/NB NS/PB/ZE NM/PS/NS NB/PS/NM NM/ZE/ZE NM/PS/NB
PB ZE/PM/PS ZE/PM/PS NS/PB/ZE NM/PB/ZE NM/PB/ZE NM/PS/PS NM/PS/NB

sec.title: 4.4. Fuzzy inference and defuzzification
sec.p: The fuzzy inference rule used in Table 2 is if e is Ai and ec is Bj, then Δkp is Cij, Δkp is Dij and Δkp is Eij, where Ai, Bj, Cij, Dij, Eij are fuzzy subsets of inputs and outputs, and i,j=1,…,7.

The Mamdani min operators and max operators are adopted to carry out fuzzy implication and synthesis calculation respectively. Thus, the result of Δkp (Δki and Δkd are similar) is (16)uC'(Δkp)=∨i,j=17{[ui(e)∧uj(ec)]∧uCij(Δkp)}

The Centroid method is used to implement defuzzification after the output fuzzy sets C' are acquired from the fuzzy operation. The PID controller parameter Δkp is obtained as follows: (17)Δkp=∑i=149μpj(Δkp)·Δkpj∑i=149μpj(Δkp)

sec.title: 5. Simulation and experiment results
sec.p: In this section a series of numerical simulations and experiments are performed on the active rotor TPJB system based on the fuzzy PID control strategy. Firstly the modified Reynolds’ equation is solved based on the finite difference method and the hydrodynamic pressure distribution can be obtained. Then the hydrodynamic forces can be calculated by numerically integrating the pressure distribution. And then the static equilibrium points of the rotor-bearing system with moving pads based on the sum of forces and momentum can be worked out. Equations (6) and (10)–(12) can be integrated in the time domain since the oil film pressure distribution has been worked out. In order to approve the effectiveness of the active lubrication compared to the conventional lubrication, at the very start, we turned off the servo valves to analyze the conventionally lubricated system and obtain the unbalance response of the shaft rotating at a certain speed. Then the control signals at a certain instant of time can be deduced to implement the fuzzy PID controller. When the servo valves are turned on and the active lubrication work is stable in the sampling period under the controller, the corresponding results of the active system were also acquired.

Figure 5 shows the shaft displacement in y direction at bearing B when the rotor is subjected to an unbalance eccentricity at rotational speed of 12,500 r/min, with and without the active lubrication. By comparison, we can find that once the control system is turned on, the vibration amplitude of the rotating shaft is dramatically reduced in y direction and the active bearing manages to reduce the rotor eccentricity. Figure 5.
Time response history with and without control.

When the rotational speed is increased to the critical case, the instability phenomenon of whirl emerged in the results of the unbalanced eccentricity. This phenomenon is characterized by high vibration amplitudes and sub-harmonic components close to half of the rotating frequency. And the unstable rotational speed of the conventional system and the active system can be worked out respectively. Then we can draw the rotor response vibration amplitude-frequency characteristic chart, three dimensional spectrum and bifurcation diagram of bearing B as shown in Figure 6 and Figure 7. Figure 6.
Comparison of frequency-response curves at bearing B.
Figure 7.
Comparison of bifurcation diagram of different systems; (a) conventional system; (b) active system.

From Figure 6 we can see that the synchronous vibration is occurring at power frequency and the amplitude is very small when the rotational speed is below 10,050 r/min in the conventional case. The same conclusion can be reached from Figure 7. When the rotational speed is greater than 10,050 r/min, the response of the system is quasi periodic motion and the vibration amplitude of the rotor is significantly increased at a certain rotational speed. Compared with the conventional case, the unstable rotational speed (whirl) of the active system appeared at 13,040 r/min, moreover, the instability amplitude of the active system is much smaller than the conventional case.

As shown in Figure 8, the dimensionless rotor orbits at bearing B at different rotational speeds (5500, 11,500, 13,000, 15,500 r/min) have also been obtained and compared. The displacement of the controlled system is much smaller than that of the conventional system and the misalignments of the rotor orbits for the controlled system are also much decreased. When the rotational speed of the rotor is 11,500 r/min and 13,000 r/min, the motions of the conventional system are quasi periodic, while the controlled system stays periodic. These results confirm the feasibility of using active bearings to compensate small misalignments and to increase the stable operational speed ranges. Figure 8.
Comparison of the rotor obits at bearing B. (a) Ω=5500r/min; (b) Ω=11500r/min; (c) Ω=13000r/min; (d) Ω=15500r/min.

To testify the validity of the numerical simulation of this rotor TPJB system the corresponding experiment is carried out. Figures 9 and 10 are the experimental results of the shrink of rotor orbits at different rotational speeds (5500, 11,500, 13,000, 15,500 r/min) and the comparison of three-dimensional spectrum plots at bearing B. Figure 9.
Shrink processes of the rotor obits at bearing B with control. (a) Ω=5500r/min; (b) Ω=11500r/min; (c) Ω=13000r/min; (d) Ω=15500r/min.
Figure 10.
Comparison of three-dimensional spectrum plots; (a) conventional system; (b) active system.

Figure 9 clearly shows that the shrink processes of the rotor obits at bearing B with control, and the measured stable rotor obits are almost the same with the simulation results in Figure 8. Figure 10 shows that the whirl phenomenon occurred when the rotational speed arrived at about 10,090 r/minfor the conventional system and 13,100 r/minfor the active system correspondingly. These results demonstrate that the vibration amplitudes of the rotating parts can be obviously reduced and the stable operational speed ranges can be greatly broadened by the actively lubricated system using the fuzzy PID controller. And the active lubricated bearing can also be applied to put off the instabilities (whirl) of the rotor-bearing system, which illustrates one of its most promising applications.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p:
In conclusion, the nonlinear dynamic model of an overhang rotor with double discs supported by a couple of TPJBs has been formulated in this paper. The rotor-bearing system studied here consists of two TPJBs, one of which is actively lubricated by the servo valves while another one is conventionally lubricated. The nonlinear differential equations of motion for the conventional and the active lubricated system are solved respectively. The finite difference method is applied to figure out the oil film pressure distribution on each tilting pad surface of the actively lubricated system. Then the frequency responses of both systems have been worked out and compared. The corresponding experiments have been carried out to evaluate the effectiveness of the fuzzy PID control method for this rotor TPJB system. The following conclusions can be drawn from the results:
Numerical results show that the vibration amplitudes of the rotor system can be significantly reduced and the misalignments are obviously compensated by applying the active TPJB with a fuzzy PID controller.
The emergency of the whirl instability effects are greatly put off and the range of the stable running speed can be extended by the actively lubricated TPJB system based on a fuzzy PID controller.
The experiment results shows that the numerical simulations are correct and the application of such active bearings in controlling the instabilities phenomenon will have a bright prospect.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant numbers 10772056, 10632040) and the Natural Science Foundation of Hei-Long-Jiang Province, China (grant number ZJG0704).
